frameDefinitions: A Communicator announces (linguistically or non-linguistically) the  imminent arrival of an Individual or the occurrence of an Event.
The  Speaker expresses through language his wish to get the Addressee to act in some way that will help to bring about events or states described in the Content.
In this frame a Speaker asks an Addressee for something, or to carry out some action.
This frame contains verbs and nouns that communicate the act of a Speaker to address a Message to some Addressee using language.

A Speaker talks about a Topic, which may be an action performed by the Speaker or an entity or state of affairs that they are associated with in order to suggest that the Speaker is worthy of admiration.
frameExamples: The unveiling of Alinghi's keel was <t>heralded</t> by alp horns
Mr Smithers always <t>encourages</t> the employees to stay late and work harder.
I now <t>declare</t> you members of this Society.
Turkish officials <t>boasted</t> of giving 'tens of thousands of dollars in surreptitious payments' to a prominent American politician.
listRoleDefinitions: The <fen>Communicator</fen> greets the arrival of an <fen>Individual</fen> or occurrence of an <fen>Event</fen>.
The person who is greeted at their arrival by the <fen>Communicator</fen>.
The occurrence which is greeted by the <fen>Communicator</fen>.
The symbol-containing artifact whereby a <fen>Communicator</fen> heralds.
This role identifies the time when the <fen>Communicator</fen>  heralds.
This role identifies the place where the Communicator heralds.
The wish for action on the Addressee's part that the Speaker expresses.
The person that the <fen>Speaker</fen> seeks to influence to act.
The person who intends through the use of language to get another person to act.
What the communication is about.
The written or spoken material that contains a message that potentially influences the <fen>Addressee</fen> towards the <fen>Content</fen>.
An entity which the <fen>Speaker</fen> believes should participate in the action.
The time at which the lobbying occurs.
The location where the <fen>Speaker</fen> attemtps susaion on an <fen>Addressee</fen>.
The <fen>Speaker</fen>, as in other communication frames, is generally an External Argument.
In this frame the <fen>Addressee</fen> can either occur as an NP Object (usually with a following complement clause) or as a PP Complement of verbs or nouns.
The <fen>Message</fen> is the content of the request that can be expressed as a quote, in a finite or non-finite clausal Complement, an NP Object or PP Complement.

The <fen>Medium</fen> is the physical entity or channel used to transmit the <fen>Message</fen>. The <fen>Medium</fen> is frequently expressed as a PP Complement headed by <ment>on</ment> or <ment>in</ment>.
The interval during which the <fen>Speaker</fen> makes the request.

The <fen>Speaker</fen> is the sentient entity that produces the <fen>Message</fen> (whether spoken or written).  It is normally expressed as the External Argument of predicative uses of the <t>target	</t> word, or as the Genitive modifier of the noun.
The <fen>Message</fen> is the role that identifies the content of what the <fen>Speaker</fen> is communicating to the <fen>Addressee</fen>.  It can be expressed as a clause or as a noun phrase.
The <fen>Topic</fen> is the subject matter to which the <fen>Message</fen> pertains. It is normally expressed as a PP Complement headed by 'about', but in some cases it can appear as a direct object.
<fen>Medium</fen> is the physical entity or channel used by the <fen>Speaker</fen> to transmit the statement.
The <fen>Time</fen> at which the <fen>Message</fen> is made.
The role specifies the location where the <fen>Message</fen> takes place.
The <fen>Speaker</fen> is the person who produces a message about a <fen>Topic</fen>.
The <fen>Topic</fen> is a positively judged entity or state of affairs with which the <fen>Speaker</fen> is associated and about which they talk.
<fen>Medium</fen> is the physical entity or channel used by the <fen>Speaker</fen> to transmit the statement.
A description of the state of affairs that redounds to the <fen>Speaker</fen>'s credit
<fen>Expressor</fen> is the body part or action that conveys the feeling of pride of the <fen>Speaker</fen>.
The time when the statement is made.
The role specifies the place where the statement takes place.
listRoleExamples: Sheep scattered from the road as trumpets heralded <fex>his arrival at the castle gates</fex>
<fex>The judge</fex> ordered the plaintiff to return the money.
The child implored <fex>her parents</fex> to let her stay up late.
The parents of the missing child made an appeal <fex>on television</fex>.
Evelyn said <fex>that she was not ready to leave</fex>.
Kim preached to me <fex>over the phone</fex>.
In some remarks <fex>at the National Press Club</fex>, Mr. Keating said he would make a better prime minister tha nMr. Hawke.
During the 1990s <fex>Rio Grande Do Sul's governor, Olivio Dutra of the PT,</fex> PREENED about the province's GE-free status.
Mike Wallace was told that Canseco had bragged <fex>about steroids</fex>.
CNN's Jeff Greenfield bragged <fex>on the air</fex> recently that ratings are high.
Cosmai BRAGGED <fex>that Hyundai's latest quality rankings place the automaker on par with Honda and Toyota</fex>.
The senator's boastful <fex>exaggerations of her academic record at a New Hampshire campaign event</fex> also contributed to her withdrawal.

The public does not care, but the media definitely do as Haddock herself boasted
<fex>the next morning</fex> on Good Morning America.
'I'm Pat Crowe,' he boasted <fex>at the police station</fex>.
